concept.title: Folder Structure Overview
concept.shortdesc: Learn how content is organized in the Author-it Library using folders. This section explains folder types, their purpose, and best practices for managing objects.

conbody.p: Folders help authors and designers organize content within the library.

ul.li: Names and hierarchy are fully customizable.
Users can create as many folders as their team requires.
The structure can evolve over time without disrupting existing relationships.

section.title: Recommended Folder Structure
section.p: Author-it follows a three-tier folder organization model. Each tier supports different workflows and security needs.

p.i: Figure 5: Quick view of the folder structure model

li.p: Used for reusable objects that appear across many documents.
Security: Typically open. Authors can add, update, or reuse objects freely.
The main space where authors perform daily work.

ul.li: Stores books and topics under development.

Can be organized by:
Department (e.g., HR, Technical Publications)
Product (e.g., X1000, X2000)
Document type (e.g., User Guide, Admin Guide)

li.p: Flexibility: Folders can be renamed or reorganized at any time without affecting book relationships.
Controlled space for designers and administrators.
Security: Read-only for authors. Only designers/admins can modify or delete content.

section.title: Working with Folders in the Library Interface

p.i: Figure 6: A visual guide to create a new folder

ul.li: Navigate to the left panel and select the open folder.
Drag and drop objects to change their “home address.”
Moving an object does not break its connection to books.
The folder selected in the Folders Pane becomes the object's home.
If the object was created in the wrong folder, simply drag it to the correct one.

note.p: Drag-and-drop is the most reliable method for organizing content throughout the library.
